Format is: [scriptSig, scriptPubKey, flags, expectedScriptError, ... comments]
It is evaluated as if there was a crediting coinbase transaction with two 0
pushes as scriptSig, and one output of 0 atoms and given scriptPubKey,
followed by a spending transaction which spends this output as only input (and
correct prevout hash), using the given scriptSig. All lock times are 0 and
There should be an empty stack after scriptSig evaluation
and multiple spaces should not change that
Similarly whitespace around and between symbols
There should be an empty stack after scriptSig evaluation
and multiple spaces should not change that
Entries with hex notation are treated as raw bytes (OP_TRUE)
Both OP_NAME and NAME are valid
Entries with hex notation are treated as raw bytes (OP_FALSE)
Single quoted strings are pushed as data
Single quoted numeric strings are pushed as data
Single quoted strings with brace suffix are repeated
Raw bytes in hex notation with brace suffix are repeated
Multiple tokens in angular brackets with with brace suffix are repeated
'abc'{3} results in a single push of 9 bytes while <'abcabcabc'>{2} is 2 pushes of 9 bytes each
Execution result with non-zero value is success
All bytes are significant, not only the last one
Result is based on raw bytes, not numeric interpretation (equals zero when cast to int64, which would be OP_FALSE)
NOTE: Hashing is used here instead of a basic EQUAL check because minimal
data encoding requirements intentionally prevent pushing the expected
Basic PUSH signedness check rejected by minimal data encoding requirements
Basic PUSHDATA1 signedness check rejected by minimal data encoding requirements
PUSHDATA1 of 75 bytes equals direct push of it but rejected by minimal data encoding requirements
NOTE: OP_PUSHDATA4 is not possible to use without error due to the minimal
data requirements enforcing a smallest data push with it of 65,536 which is
greater than the max script size of 16,384
Empty vector minimally represented by OP_0 (OP_PUSHDATA1)
Empty vector minimally represented by OP_0 (OP_PUSHDATA2)
Empty vector minimally represented by OP_0 (OP_PUSHDATA4)
1 to 16 minimally represented by OP_1 to OP_16
PUSHDATA1 of 72 bytes minimally represented by direct push
PUSHDATA2 of 255 bytes minimally represented by PUSHDATA1
PUSHDATA4 of 256 bytes minimally represented by PUSHDATA2
Numeric MINIMALDATA rules are only applied when a stack item is numerically evaluated; the push itself is allowed

The following is useful for checking implementations of script number interpretation
Leave room for the sign bit
Numbers are little-endian with the MSB being a sign bit
We can do math on 4-byte integers, and compare 5-byte ones
... but they are numerically equal but rejected by minimal data encoding requirements

CHECKMULTISIG evaluation order tests. CHECKMULTISIG evaluates signatures and
pubkeys in a specific order, and will exit early if the number of signatures
left to check is greater than the number of keys left. As strict encoding fails the
script when it reaches an invalidly encoded signature or pubkey, we can use it
to test the exact order in which signatures and pubkeys are evaluated by
distinguishing CHECKMULTISIG returning false on the stack and the script as a
2-of-2 CHECKMULTISIG NOT with the second pubkey invalid, and both signatures validly encoded. Valid pubkey fails, and CHECKMULTISIG exits early, prior to evaluation of second invalid pubkey.
2-of-2 CHECKMULTISIG NOT with both pubkeys valid, but second signature invalid. Valid pubkey fails, and CHECKMULTISIG exits early, prior to evaluation of second invalid signature.
2-of-2 CHECKMULTISIG NOT with the first pubkey invalid, and both signatures validly encoded
2-of-2 CHECKMULTISIG NOT with both pubkeys valid, but first signature invalid
While not really correctly DER encoded, the empty signature is allowed by
strict encoding to provide a compact way to provide a delibrately invalid signature.

CHECKMULTISIGVERIFY zero sigs means no sigs or pubkeys are checked
